1043936667961364480.text:
The folks I’ve heard with the best product philosophies can articulate it incredibly clearly and directly. It’s usually dead simple.

You and I will hopefully get there one day. Until then, keep defining and refining.

1043936665834786817.text:
At first, you won’t be able to succinctly articulate your product philosophy. That’s usually because it’s too long and complicated and has lots of caveats. That means you haven’t yet discovered what is *really* important.

I’m still at this stage.

1043936664110927878.text: A philosophy will of course evolve over time. You’ll be wrong about stuff often. But having a baseline philosophy allows you to operate within it, apply it to your current product challenges, and adjust over time based on outcomes.

1043936662080933890.text: Great products use data and research to inform them, but product philosophy and conviction is what guides you directionally, and help you break the myriad of “ties” you encounter. You simply can’t afford to experiment on or research everything.

1043936659153309697.text: A “how to build it” personal philosophy is important because all standard frameworks and processes *will* break down eventually, or not make sense for what you’re building. Frameworks can never fully account for your specific context, so you’ll need to call audibles often.

1043936654795440129.text:
There’s a lot of advice on product floating around out there.

But something I don’t see enough (and what I wish I learned earlier) is to start developing a personal philosophy on product - both what makes good product and how to build it.

978825884231766016.text: Anyway, curious if other people have had experiences like this that took a small amount of time, but left a lasting impact.

978825882969296897.text: Obviously, the core of it is living within that budget each and every day. But setting that direction and mentally committing to it was something that had to happen once in a compressed period of time. Not sure how things might look for me now if that never happened.

978825881522143232.text:
I committed to living within this budget, except under rare circumstances. I revisit this budget once a year to adjust for any changes in my life.

5 years later, I can genuinely believe those 2 hours to have been amongst the most impactful hours in my life.

978825878246486018.text:
The one that affected me most was when I graduated college and got my first job. I sat down for 2 hours to figure out my personal spending budget. 

I broke down spending on necessities, a bit of discretionary spending that I could thankfully afford, and a savings model.

978825877025849344.text:
But there’s an even more extreme version of this. Something that you might do only once or infrequently that sets you up for long periods of time, if not a lifetime. These could take an hour, a day, a week.

I want to discover more of these.

978825875029397505.text: I’ve been thinking a lot about the Pareto principle lately (80% of ROI comes from 20% of work). It’s fascinating to think about how you might be spending a lot more energy for minimal gain.

972227597357608960.text: In other words, if you’re a GM, you better make sure you’re selecting Michael Jordan and not Sam Bowie. There’s a lot more than you thought riding on it.

972227596317442048.text: This could skew an entire younger generation’s perception on how to assemble a team and formulate a strategy, something they may take with them for the rest of their lives.

972227595164041216.text: Not only does a single draft pick have the potential to lift a team and subsequently re-ignite a local economy, it may also validate/invalidate an entire front office strategy.

972227593997971456.text: Following this train of thought...this only exacerbates the importance of high draft selections to a city.

972227593003872256.text: It’s intriguing to imagine how these lessons may be re-applied 35 years later by kids who grew up fans of those teams, in whatever context they eventually find themselves in.

972227591921745920.text:
A Patriot’s fan might prioritize key-position leadership and continuity.

A Spurs fan might value a deep rotation of stable, but understated talent.

A Yankees fan might prioritize big-name, splashy hires with price being no object.

972227590701301760.text:
Team roster strategy and personnel management is often a kid’s first exposure to this type of thinking.

If you’re 8, and you watch your favorite team rebuild through the draft vs rebuild by landing superstar free agents, doesn’t that leave a lasting impression on you?

972227589593972736.text: Crazy theory: the management and strategy of a professional sports team in a given city plays a non-trivial role in shaping the business philosophy of a city’s younger generation.
